Annuities, Private.

A memorial of all deeds, &c. for granting annuities for.one or more lives or years, or greater eftates determinable on lives, to be inrolled in chancery in 20 days. 17 G. 3. c. 26. vol. 3 1.

Before judgment entered cn ay warrant of attorney for fecuring any annuity, and before execution, the memorial lg to be inrolled as above. Same ad, §

All fuch deeds to contain the confi-deration paid and the names of the parties at length, and if any part of the confideration mentioned is returned or retained, the court where any adion is brought may fiay the proceedings, and order the deeds to be cancelled. Same ad, § 3, 4.

The clerk of the inrollments in chancery to keep a particular roll for annuities, and to Ipecify the exad time of inroilment, and to be paid is. for the firft 200 words, and 6d. for each 100 words after, and is. for every fearch. Same ad, § 5.

All contrads with infants under age for annuities to be void, and for procuring the fame, liable to fine and im-prifonment; and folicitors, feriveners, and brokers, taking more than 10s. per cent, for procuring, &c. fubjed to the like punifhment. Same ad, § 6 & 7.

Not to extend to annuities or rent-charges by wills, marriage fettlements, or for advancing children, nor if fe-enred on lands of equal or greater value, or if the grantor is feifed in fee or tail, or if fecured by flock actually transferred, if the dividend be of greater value, nor to extend to voluntary annuities, without pecuniary confideration,

Standard wheaten bread to weigh •three-fourths of the wheat whereof it is made, to be marked S. W. and the peck loaf to weigh feventeen pounds fix ounces avoirdupois, and leflFer loaves in proportion. Seven itandard loaves

33

equal to eight wheaten, or to fix houfe-hold loaves. 13 G. 3. c. 62. § 2. vol. 30*

Standard wheaten bread not to be fold as priced loaves at the fame time ; but magiftrates may fet the price and affize of ftandard wheaten bread according to the tables *to this aft; and bakers to be liable to the fame penalties as by the laws in being; Same aft, § 4k

If a baker informed again ft for making ftandard wheaten bread not of the whole produce of the wheat (except bran) fhall prove that he bought the flour of a miller, aud give in his name and place of abode, fuch miller to be liable to the penalties of 31 G. 2. c. 29. Same aft, § 6.

Where juft ices have fet the price of ftandard w'heaten bread, they may omit other forts, and prohibit the felling of other than ftandard wheaten bread for three months, on giving one month's notice; but the bakers company of London may objeft to fuch prohibition; and penny and two-penny loaves may be fold as by 31 G. 2. and coarfer bread liibjeft to the fame aft; but if fold as price bread, liibjeft to penalties, and the magiftrates to have the fame power as by any law in being; but not to extend to the cuftom of London or Weftminfter, or the rights of the twfo univerfities: and’ all laws concerning bread to remain in corporations: where there are two bailiffs, one is to fet the affize of bread. Fifth rate of building, viz. dwell-inghoufes, (tables, and other buildings (except buildings not being dwell-inghoufes, and of the id rate) at the diliance of four feet, and not eight feet from any public road, dreet, or caufe-way, and detached from any other building, not in the fame poffedion, 16 feet at lead, and not 30 feet, or connefted only by a fence wall, to be of the 5th rate, ana may be built of any dimenfions. Sixth rate of building, viz. clwelling-houfes, warehoufes, dables, and other buildings (except fuch buildings not being dwellinghoufes, and of the id rate) which are eight feet from any public road, dreet, or caufevvay, and detached from any other building, not in the fame poffeilion, 30 feet, 01 connefted only by a fence-wall, to be of the 6th rate, and may be built of any dimenfions, or of any materials. Same aft, §19.

Seventh rate of building, viz. crane-houfes on wharfs or quays, (hambles, wind or water mills, and all buildings out of London and Wedminder, and liberties, and ufed for workdiops, or cliyingplaces for tanners, felimongers, gluemakers, fizemakers, callico-printers, whitders, whitingmakcYs, curriers, lea-tberdreffers, buckramfliffeners, oilcloth-painters, woolftaplei s, throw (lers, parchment and papermakers, fo long as ufed for 1 hole purpofes, of the 7th rate, and may be built of any dimenfions j external inclofures of cranehouleg to be of done, brick, (late, tyle, oak, elm, Ocel, iion, or brafs, but other buildings of the faid rate, may be of any materials, fo that they be not covered with pitch, tar, or other inflammable compofilion, and not ufed for other purpofes. Same aft, § 20, 21.

Detached offices, or if only con-nefted by fence-walls, to be deemed of the rate fuch office would be of, if the fame did not appertain to any other building, and old found party-w'ails to remain ; if the adjoining building is rebuilt without making uieof fuch wall, the owner of the other part to have only one-half of fuch old wall .and ground when pulled down: if party-walls are not of the thicknefs aforefaid, to be condemned as ruinous; and alio if it (ball have any timber through it, to be cut off fo as not to leave fix inches of brickwork. Timber partitions to remain till one of the adjoining houfes be taken dow n or condemned as ruinous, and no longer; and external walls not to become party-walls, unlefs of the height and thickneis, and of inch materials as before direfted. Same aft, § 24, 25.

Candles.

Candles and other goods enumerated which have paid duties, may be exported on notice to excife officers, who are to fee the fame packed, &c. 23 G. 3. c. 74. vol. 34.

An additional excife duty of one halfpenny per pound laid on all candles, either imported or home made (except wax or fpermaceti) and alfo 3 per cent, import: on the duties by 19 & 22 G. 3. and feveral regulations made for fecur-ing the fame duties; and after ift of Augurt, no compofjtion allowed on candles for private ufe. 24 G. 3. fef. 2. c-

ii.	vol. 34.

See Wax Candles. Same year, c. 36.

None to make candles in the limit* of the excife office, London, but the occupiers of tenements of at leaft iol. per ann. befides the parifh rates; and in other parts of the kingdom without paying to church and poor. 2c G. 3* c. 74. § 25. vol. 3;.

The time of entering home-made candles reduced to a week, and to be on oath, and the duty to be paid in a week after; and notice to officers when the makers begin to fpread cotton, and to begin working in three hours after, or the notice void. Same a&, § 24.

Candlemakers having begun to fpread wicks, mu ft proceed till all for the courfe be finifhed ; and alfo begin to dip in five hours after beginning to fpread, and continue to dip till the courfe is finifhed, on penalty of 50I. and if the notice fpecifies more than five hours, ta be void. 26 G. 3. c. 77. § 6. vol. 33.

Entries of candlemakers not deemed withdrawn till all arrears of duties paidT 27 G. 3. c. 31. § 18. vol. 36.

Officers of excife not to enter candlemakers houfes from eleven at night till five in the morning, without a peace officer, except where candles are-in operation, or notice given of working. Same a&, § 20.

Game*

Taking* killing* or deftroying, st hare, pheafant, partridge, moor game, heath game, or groufe, between an hour after iun-fet and the like time before fun-rifing, or ufing dog, gun, fnare, net, or engine, for that purpofe, in the night, for the fir it offence impi i-fonmenr, not more than fix nor lels than three months, and in three days to be whipped. 10 G. 3. c. 19. §1. vol.

28.

The like offence on Sunday to forfeit not more than 30I. nor lefs than 2d. to be levied by diitrel's with colts, one moiety to the informer, and the other to the poor ; and, for want of diftrefs, to be committed for not more than fix, nor lefs than three, months, with appeal to the quarter feflions, who may give colts, and to be final, and not removed by Certiorari. Same aft, § 2.

Killing black game between the 10th of December and the 20th of Auguft, red game between the 10th of Decern-, ber and the 12th of Augult, and buf-tards between the ift of March and the lit of September, for the firll offence to forfeit not more than 20I. nor lefs than iol. and for every other offence not lefs than 20I. nor more than 30I. Not to extend to Scotland. 2 G. 3. c. 19, as to black game ; and groufe called red game, repealed. 13 G. 3. c. 55. vol. 30.

Aft 10 G. 3. c. 19. as to killing game in the night, altered to between 7 at night and 6 in the morning, from the 12th of February to the 12th of October, and between 9 at night and 4 in the morning the reft of the year; for the firll offence to forfeit not lefs than 1 ol. nor more than 20I.; for the fecond offence not lefs than 20I. nor more than 30U; and for any other offence to be committed till the next general quarter feftions, or bound over as well as the informer ; and if convifted to pay 50I. and committed till payment, but not for lefs than fix months, nor more than twelve ; and to be whipped at the end of imprifonment. 13 G. 3. c. 80. § 1. vol. 30.

/ Hawkers and Pedlars.

*

An additional duty of 4I. per annum laid on hawkers and pedlars; and .thofe travelling with a horie, or other bead of burthen, to pay a further duty, of eight pounds per annum for each borfe, &c. be Tides all former duties* as G. 3. c. 78. § 1. vol. 35.

Selling goods in any heufe not his own without licence, penalty 50I.; and travelling without licence, or with a forged one, or refilling to fhew it, or lending fuch licence for hire to another, or expofing goods to fale in nqy city or market town, or within two miles thereof (except on fair or market days) ; and alio conftables refuling to affitl, to forfeit 10I. for each offence. Same ad, § 2.

No hawker, &c. to vend goods in any cointfy where the quarter-leffions have made an order to the contrary, under the fame penalty as trading without licence. Same ad, §11.

For forging licences, or hawkers trading without, to forfeit iool.; and for lending it, or trading with a lent one, 4°k Same ad, § 12.

Hawkers, See. licenced before 23d June 1785, may fet up bulinefs in any' place where they refide, though not brought up thereto, and may employ thofe who have not been apprentices ; and no wholesale trader in Englifh lace, woollen, linen, lilk, cotton, or mixed, or other kind of Britifh goods, to be deemed a hawker. Same ad, § 13.

This ad not to extend to fellers of printed papers (licenced by authority) or fifh, Fruits, or viduals, or the real makers of Britifh goods felling the

fame, or to their children, apprentices,

agents, or fervants; or expofing the fame to fale in any city or town, nor to travelling tinkers, coopers, glaziers,* plumbers, or harneis menders. Same ad, § 15.

Jamaica•

The ports of Kingfton, Savannah la Mar, Montego Bay, and Santa Lucia, in Jamaica (and other Britifli ports in the Weft-Indies) opened for the free impor-tion, in one-decked veffels, of live cattle, and all goods the growth or produce of any foreign colony in America (except fugar, coffee, pimento, ginger, melaffes and tobacco) ; but no foreign manufactures to be imported thither, on forfeiture of the goods and veffel. 6 G. 3. c. 49. vol. 27.—13 G. 3. c. 73.—14 G.

3.	c. 41. vol. 30.—21 G. 3. c. 29. vol. 33.—27 G. 3. c. 27. vol. 36.

And after the firft of September, 1766, no copper ore, cotton wool, ginger, fuftick, or other dying woods, hemp, indigo, melaffes, beaver (kins, or furs, fugar, cocoa, coffee, pimento, hides, (kins, pot or pearl allies, raw filk, or whale fins, to be imported into any of the faid ports, on forfeiture of Hup and cargo. 6 G. 3. c. 49. vol. 27.

But wool, or other enumerated goods of foreign growth, may be imported from Jamaica or Dominica to Great Britain dirertly, as allowed by arts 12, 22, and 23 Cba. 2. Same art, § 7.

Duties to be paid into the chief offices of excife in London or Edinburgh, and in other places to the collectors of excife licences, to continue in force until the tenth of October next enfuing the granting thereof, and if granted between April and October, a rateable proportion to be charged, and licences to be renewed yearly. On death or removal of licenced perfons, commiffioners of excife, &c. may authorife the executors or alfignees to carry on the trade for the remainder of the term. Same act, § 10.

One licence fuffiqent where a partner-fhip in 6ne houfe, but not to authorife the fale of wine, &c. in any other houfe than that for w'hich granted. Same act, § 10.

Not to prejudice the privilege of the two univerfities, nor the vintners company of London ; but freemen by redemption to take out licences. Same act, § 12.

All former militia laws (except thofe relating to London, the Tower Hamlets, and the Cinque Ports) are repealed, but not to annul commiffions already granted under them, where the parties are legally qualitied 1 and proceedings of meetings under former afts to be valid. 26 G. 3.C 107. § 13$. vol. 3$.

Magiftrates may billet militiamen, and imprefs carriages for them on their march, at the rate of is. per mile for 5 horfes or 6 oxen, or with 4 oxen and 2. horfes, at qd per mile ; aud all furplus of expence above the rates to be paid by the treafurer of the county, who is alfo to pay the expence of relieving lick men. Mulkets to be marked (M) ; penalty for felling arms 3I. and a commitment to the houfe of correction for 3 months on non-payment; and for buying arm* 5I. penalty, and the like commitment for non-payment. Same act, § 83.

Militiamen may be put under flop-pages to buy them neceflaries; and the fubaltern officers, when the militia are not embodied, may be tried by a court-martial, and may be reduced to ferve as private men. Same act, §87.

The king may direct the militia to be embodied in cafe of invafion, rebellion, or infurreftion, which is to be communicated to parliament, if fitting; if not, to be declared by proclamation ; and when thus embodied, to be fubjeft to the articles of war ; but not to be ordered out of Great Britain. Same a&, § 95. '

When the militia is called out, the king may iflue a proclamation for the meeting of parliament in fourteen days ; and county lieutenants to iflue orders accordingly. Same aft, § 98.

Militia officers not to lit on trials of officers of other forces; the commanding officer may appoint an agent, who is to give fecurity for the pay, clothing, and public Hock of the regiment or company. Same aft, § 99.

When the militia is ordered out, the receiver general of the land tax is to pay one guinea for the ufe of each militiaman, for which the commanding officer is to account to the men ; and in cafe the term of fervice is prolonged beyond five years, then each man to have one guinea whofe time is fo prolonged ; and if for three years more, another guinea in like manner, and fo for every three years; and the commander is to lay out fuch money for the bed advantage of the men, and account to them for the fame. Same aft, §101.

The militia when embodied, entitled to the fame pay as the other forces ; and if maimed in fervice, to have the benefit of Chelfea hofpital; and when difembodied, to be only fubjeft to orders as before drawn out. Same aft, § 103.

New fabricks to pay 181. percent. ad valorem^ according to the price at London, on the oath of the maker, and if undervalued, may be taken to the next excife office, and fold to pay the duty ; and the furplus, one moiety to the officer, and the other to the exchequer. Same aft, § q.

Same aft, §^. The claufe, § ^.repealed. 28 G. 3. c. 50. vol. 36.

On pledging goods, to take a dupli 1 cate, and the perfon producing the fame, to be deemed the owner ; and on being paid the principal and profit, the pawnbroker to deliver the goods, unlefs he have notice of the real owner, or the duplicate be loft. 24 G. 3. c. 42.

§ 4. vol. 34.

If the duplicate is loft, an affidavit to be made thereof; which is declared to be an indemnity to the pawnbroker. Same a cl, § 5.

Goods pawned for above ten (hillings, and for lets than ten pounds, if not redeemed in a year, may be fold by auction (but not otherwife) by the pawnbroker after the end of the year ; and a book of account to be kept of fuch fales, and the overplus to be paid to the owner ; and juft ices may caul’e pawnbrokers to produce fuch books on penalty of iol. Same aft, § 6.

Pawnbrokers to take licences, and pay ftamp duties for the iame annually, viz. redding in London, Weftminfter, St. Mary-le-Bone, or Pancras, or within the bills of mortality, or Southwark, to pay iol. and in other parts of Great Britain, 5I. ; to be granted by the com-miffioners of {lamps, and renewed yearly ; and not to keep more than one (hop for each licence. 25 G. 3. c. 48. $ 6. vol. 35.

Pawnbrokers allowed to take the fame rates for profit as before mentioned ; and the parties may redeem within feven clays after the end of the firft month, without paying any thing extra for thofe feven days , or within fourteeen days, 6n paying for one month and an half; but parties applying to redeem after fourteen days, muft pay for the fceond month ; and the like regulations are to be obferved in every fuofequent month, when application (hall be made to redeem. 27 G. 3. c. 37. § 12. vol. 36.

For counterfeiting pawnbrokers notes, liable to be committed for three months, and not under one month. Same aft, § 6.

The like puniftiment for offering to pawn goods, and the party not giving

a good account of themfelves. Same aft, § 7.

If goods are unlawfully pawned, the broker to reftore them on being repaid, or to be committed till fatisfac-tion made. Same aft, § 8.

Perfons producing notes deemed owners, and if the note is loft, the broker to give a copy. Same aft,

§ 10.

Goods pawned deemed forfeited at the end of one year; but the owner may give notice not to fell them for feven days beyond the year. Same aft,

§ 12.

Hours of pawning limited; and if goods are fold before forfeited, or hurt, the br)ker to make fatisfaftion, with a penalty of iol. Same aft,

§ *9*

Pawnbrokers to produce their book* when neceffary, and if not kept regularly, to forfeit iol. and for other offences 5I. each; to be levied by diftrei’s. Same aft, §21.

Juftices may order 50s. of the penalty to the profecutor, and the reft; to the poor of the parifti; but infoima-tion muft be given in twelve months. Same aft, § 22.

This aft not to extend to perfons lending money at 5I. per cent, without further profit. Same aft, § 24.

For further regulating the trade of a awnbroker, pawns to be entered in ooks, and to give notes, deferibing things pawned ; if any perfon, knowingly, (hall pawn the goods of others, to forfeit 20s. and alfo the value of the goods fo pawned, to be afeertained by tlie juftice, which, if not forthwith paid, to be committed to hard labour three months, and not lefs than one month, if forfeitures not fooner paid. 27 G. 3. c. 37. § 5. vol. 35.-29 G. 3. c. 57. vol. 36.

Churchwardens and overfeers of the poor to profecute ; and inhabitants of laces where offences arecommitted.may e witnefies, and appeal allowed to the quarter fellions. Same aft, § 23. and 30.

Quebec.

Declared that all the territories in North America belonging to Great Britab, in a line fouth of the Bay of Chaleuii along the high lands dividing the rivers running into the river St. Lawrence from thofe falling into the fea, to a point forty-five degrees north latitude on the eaft bank of the river Connecticut in the fame latitude, weft, through Lake Champlain to the river St. Lawrence, thenee up the fame river to Lake Ontario, and through the fame to the river Niagara, and thence along the eaft and fouth-eaft bank of Lake Erie, till it is interfeded by the north boundary of the province of Pen-fylvania, and along the north and weft boundaries of the fame, till it ftrikes the river Ohio; but if not fo interfeded, then to the point of the bank neareft to the north-weft angle of Pen-fylvania, and from thence along the weft boundary till it ftrikes the river Ohio; and along the banks weft to the river Mifliffippi, and north to the fouth boundary of the Hudfon’s Bay company ; and alfo all territories, &c. mde part of the government of Newfound

A	Receipts

For two pounds, and under twenty pouods, to pay twopence duty; and for more than twenty pounds, to pay

fourpence; and on all receipts in full for any Turn, fourpence, to be paid for by the perfon requiring the fame ; and the payer may provide (lamps, and charge it to the receiver. 23 G. 3. c* 49. vol. 34.

Receipts in or upon deeds or bonds, and letters of acknowledgement, and receipts by Teamen or ioldiers for wages or penfions, exempt from (lamp duty; and this ad not to extend to receipts on foreign bills of exchange, or bills in Scotland, for left than 21s. Same aft, $ 7.

Notes and bills of exchange for lefs than ten pounds payable on demand, to pay threepence (lamp duty 5 and copies of foreign bills to pay fix-pence each; but bank notes exempt, the bank having agreed to pay i2,oool. per annum. Same alt, £ 9.

For fraudulently evading thefe duties, penalty 20I.; and the duty on bills of exchange to be paid by the drawer. Same ad, § 12.

Undamped receipts for lefs than two pounds, may be given in evidence for the fum exprefled therein, but not as a difeharge of all demands; and bills. Zee. marked with a three-penny (lamp, may have another added thereto. Same aft, § ic.

For fraudulently evading the duties by giving receipts for lefs than the money paid, penalty 20I.; undamped receipts may be given in evidence, but not in full, except for (locks apd dividends in the funds and drawbacks. 24 G. 3. fef. 1. c. 7. vol. 34.

After the 25th of March, 1784, none to write or fign any bill of exchange, promiffory note, or receipt liable to damp duty, except on damped paper, on penalty of five pounds ; and any neighbouring judice may determine the offence on complaint within twelve months. Same ad, § 9.

back of the main AernpoA to a perpendicular line from the tore part ot the main AernpoA under the bowfprit, from which fubfiraft three-fifths of the breadth, the remainder is the length of the keel, to find the tonnage; and the breadth from the outfide plank, in the broadeft place of the (hip, above or below the main whales, exclufive of all doubling planks wrought on the tides of the fiiip, multiplying the length of the keel by the breadth to taken, and that produft by half the breadth, and dividing the whole by 94, the quotient is the true contents of the tonnage. To afcertain the tonnage of (hips,, viz. drop a plumb line over the (tern, and meafure the diftance from thence to the after-part of the ftern-poft, at the load water-mark, then meafure from the top of the faid plumb-line in a parallel diredion with the water, to a perpendicular point immediately over the load water-mark at the fore part of the main flern, fubftrading from fuch meafurement the above diftance, the remainder will be the (hip’s extreme length, from which is to be deduded three inches for every foot of the toad-draught of w'ater for the rake' abaft, and alfo three-fifths of the (hip’s breadth for the rake foreward, the remainder (hall be efteemed the juft length of the keel to find the tonnage; and the breadth (hall be takem from outfide to outfide of the plank in the broadeft part of the fliip, either above or below the main whales,excluiive of all manner of (heath-ing or doubling that may be wrought upon the fide of the (hip, then multi-

plying the length of the keel for tonnage by the breadth fo taken, and that product by half the breadth, and dividing by ninety-four, the quotient (hall be deemed the true contents of the tonnage. Same ad, §14.

Sierra Leone Company.

Certain perfons incorporated, to trade to Sierra Leone, in Africa. 31 G. 3. c. 55. vol. 37.

The company may purchafe land9, and raife a capital joint Hock* Same aft, § 2.

Sublcribers to have an intereft in the capital joint hock, but the company not to borrow money, nor deal in llaves. Same aft, § 4.

Thirteen direftors to be chofen annually, and a chairman, and a deputy* chairman. Same aft, § 7.

Members of the company to have votes according to the number of fhares. Same aft, § 14.

None but proprietors to vote; and no perfon to be a director unlefs poffeff-ed of one (hare. Same aft, § 16.

The court of directors to meet when necelfary; and fub-committees may be appointed. Same aft, § 23.

A fecretary, agents, and fervants to be appointed. Same aft, §25.

A general court to be called once a year; and nine members of the company may demand a general court at any time. Same aft, § 30.

The company may make bye-laws. Same aft, § 33.

The direftors to hold a court once a month; and an accomptant to be appointed to keep books. Same aft,

§ 36-

Shares may be afligned, and the di-reftors may appoint officers withfalaries. Same ad!, § 42.

The company to hold the exclufive right to the peninfula of Sierra Leone. Same aft, § 44.

This aft to continue for thirty-one

Slaughtering Horfes.

All perfons keeping houfes, &c. for flaughtering horfes, mares, &c. or other cattle not killed for butcher's meat, are to take a licence from the quarter feflions of the county, See. upon the ceitificate of the minider and churchwardens or overfeers ; or by the mi-nifter and two fubftantial houfekeepers; but, in cafe of death, the keeper's widow may carry on the bulinefs until the next quarter l’elfions. 26 G. 3. c. 71. § 1. vol. 35.

Licences to be entered by the juf-tices, and the houfes to have an inferip-tion thereon, and to give notice thereof to the furveyor of flaughtering-houfes, and he to. take an account thereof, and of the owners of cattle brought; and the time for fhughtering to be from Odober to March, from eight of the clock in the morning till four in the afternoon; and from April to September, from fix o'clock in the morning till eight in the evening. Same ad, § 3*

Slave Trade,

Ships carrying Haves from Africa to any place beyond fea, to carry in proportion to five flaves for every three tons burthen above 20 r tons; and one flave for every additional ton ; and not more males above four feet three inches high; and in proportion to one male flave for every ton under the faid 201 tons ; and three fuch flaves (above four feet four inches high) for every additional five tons above the 201 tons; and fuch (hips to be deemed of the toniiage as regiflered by 26 G. 3.C. 60. and for exceeding the number limited, the mafier to forfeit 30I.	28	G.	3.

c. 54. vol. 36.

If more than two-fifths of the Haves be children not above four feet four inches high, then five of the furplus to be deemed equal to four flaves. Same ad, § 2.

Stolen Goods.

All perfons buying or receiving ftolen goods to be deemed guilty of a mifde-meanor, and may be profecuted accordingly, 22 G. 3. c. 58. vol. 34* •Juttices may giant fearch warrants to difeover ttolen goods ; and if fuch are found, the perfon in whofe cuf-tody deemed guilty of a mifdemeanor. adt, § 3.

Perfons offering ttolen goods to be pawned or fold, may be taken before a juftice; and if fuch perfon be under fifteen years of age, may be charged with felony within clergy; and for difeovering two other receivers, inti-tled to the king’s pardon. Same acV,

§ 4*

But no former law for punifhing fuch offenders repealed. Same aft, §6.

During the hollilities in the Britifh plantations, tobacco may be imported from any neutral port in America, or the Well Indies, or from any place in Europe. Same year, c. 38.

No tobacco or dalks above fourteen pounds, or fnuff more than ten pounds, which have been removed from the place of importation, to be removed again without a certificate. 23 G. 3^ c. 11. vol. 34.

All tobacco flalks or fnuff removed contrary to this ad, or 24 G. 2, c. 41. forfeited, with the cattle, carriages, Same ad, § 2.

No drawback tp be allowed on fnuff exported after the firll of Augull, 1785. 25 G. 3. c. 69. vol. 35.

No tobacco, fare from America (except of the growth of Spain or Portugal, or of Ireland) to be imported intoGrcat Britain, on forfeiture thereof, with the fhip and furniture# Same year, c. 81.

Yucatan, South America.
